title: The Essentials Tour
description: Discover the stories behind some of the museum’s most iconic artworks.
intro: Indulge in the sunlit bank of the River Seine in Georges Seurat’s "A Sunday on La Grande Jatte" or make a late-night stop at a New York City diner in Edward Hopper’s "Nighthawks" in this tour of the museum’s iconic collection. Founded in 1879, the Art Institute of Chicago is home to a massive collection spanning nearly all of human history. As you explore centuries of art, this tour highlights some essential landmarks—with lesser known, but equally engaging artworks—along the way. The soundtrack features the music of Andrew Bird, another Chicago essential.
intro_transcript: Hello and Welcome to the Art Institute of Chicago. I’m Nenette Luarca- Shouaf, Associate Curator of Education, Learning, and Interpretation. On this tour, you’ll learn about some of the museum’s most iconic paintings and sculptures. You’ll also be introduced to some treasures that aren’t so well-known. You’ll see artworks from 19th century France, the Aztec empire, a royal palace in Nigeria, and the United States just before World War II, among others. These artworks represent the breadth and depth of the Art Institute’s collection, which celebrates the rich cultural heritage and artist achievements of peoples all over the world. Our curators and researchers will be your guides and help to explain what you’re seeing. In some cases, the artists themselves offer insights on how they reproached making the works. There’s no right way to take this tour. You can follow the itinerary that we have provided or explore at your own pace in any order. The tour takes you upstairs and downstairs, from our historic Michigan Avenue building into the Modern Wing, and everywhere in between. Since the Art Institute was founded in 1879, the museum has been a source of pride for Chicago. We’re glad that you’ve decided to visit and we hope that it’s just one of many that you make in the future.
